node.title: Convergence problem for porous_flow
node.bodyText:
Greetings,
I am encountering convergence challenges in a seemingly straightforward porous flow problem. The solver throws either a 'Nonlinear solve did not converge due to DIVERGED_LINE_SEARCH' or a 'Nonlinear solve did not converge due to DIVERGED_MAX_IT iterations 50' error.
Has anyone encountered and successfully resolved this issue before? I would greatly appreciate any insights or solutions you can offer.
Thank you,

Hello
There are troubleshooting instructions for moose in general here
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/moose/application_usage/failed_solves.html
and some instructions to try for porous flow here
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/modules/porous_flow/tutorial_02.html
Guillaume
You don't have gravity and no fluid boundary conditions. So the simulation won't converge to any result.

Hi,
Thank you for your reply. This is a injection problem and  the BC is set up by using [DiracKernels]. The above example is based on the folder ' projects/moose/modules/combined/examples/geochem-porous_flow/geotes_2D'

I'm aware that it should work. But defining a boundary condition makes the convergence much easier.
Does the example file run standalone without MultiApp coupling to the Geochemistry module (as in the original examples)?
Unfortunately, the PorousFlow-Geochemical examples are not straightforward and easy to reproduce. Your non-convergence looks to me like non-physical values in any of the input files.
I guess more experts on the PorousFlow-Geochemistry module can help more than me.

Yes, the example can run standalone by commenting the MultiApp of geochemistry coupling.
I will double check the input file. Many thanks.
I'll try and take a look today

Well, the pressure blows up as you are injecting mass but not allowing any to leave with a BC, but I think that the default tolerance is too tight which is the main issue. Try setting something looser like 'nl_rel_tol = 1e-6' or 'nl_abs_tol = 1e-8' etc
This problem has been solved after adding producer and tolerance. Dear Chris Green @cpgr , Appreciate your quick and professional guidance.

node.title: Image Function Mesh Refinement Error when using with NS Module
node.bodyText:
I am looking for some advice on some strange errors I am getting attempting  to use Moose's NS module to predict flow through voids from a 2 phase microCT image.  Many thanks!
I first use ImageFunction with a GradientJumpIndicator to create an adaptively refined mesh which I separate into two blocks using the approach suggested in this discussion: #26733.
I then read in the refined mesh, remove the block corresponding to the solid-phase, and perform a NS analysis with unit pressure gradient (1 on the left face and zero on the right). The results of the analysis are shown below. It looks like the pressure is only being carried along certain paths were the elements are all equivalent sizes.

and here are results with no adaptive mesh refinement, just uniform refinement,
.
In addition, I had to play around with solver settings. Using the standard bjacobi preconditioner resulted in the following error which I resolved by using an asm precon. with an lu sub_pc following this page (https://mooseframework.inl.gov/modules/porous_flow/solvers.html)

  Linear solve did not converge due to DIVERGED_PC_FAILED iterations 0
                 PC failed due to SUBPC_ERROR

Step 1: Adaptive Refinement Script
[Mesh]
  [gen]
        type = GeneratedMeshGenerator
        dim = 2
        nx = 25 # = number of image pixels in x
        ny = 25 # = number of image pixels in y
    []
  [block0]
    type = SubdomainBoundingBoxGenerator
    input = 'gen'
    block_id = 0
    bottom_left = '0 0 0'
    top_right = '1 0.5 0'
  []
  [block1]
    type = SubdomainBoundingBoxGenerator
    input = 'block0'
    block_id = 1
    bottom_left = '0 0.5 0'
    top_right = '1 1 0'
  []
[]

[Functions]
    [image_func]
      type = ImageFunction
      file_base = test_images/Random_Sphers_25x_
      file_suffix = png
      file_range = '1'
      threshold = 1
      upper_value = 1
      lower_value = 0
    []
[]
  
[AuxVariables]
  [auxBlockID]
  []
[]

[AuxKernels]
  [aux_kern]
    type = FunctionAux
    variable = auxBlockID
    function = image_func
    execute_on = 'INITIAL'
  []
[]

[UserObjects]
  [change_blockID]
    type = CoupledVarThresholdElementSubdomainModifier
    coupled_var = auxBlockID
    criterion_type = ABOVE
    threshold = 0
    subdomain_id = 1
    complement_subdomain_id = 0
    execute_on = 'INITIAL'
  []
[]


[Variables]
    [u]
    []
[]

#Try use the auxillary variable in the adaptivity criterion instead of assigning it to the displacement variable
[ICs]
    [u_ic]
      type = FunctionIC
      function = image_func
      variable = u
    []
[]
  
[Problem]
    type = FEProblem
    solve = false  # that was the other way no to solve the problem, but only generate the mesh
[]
  
[Executioner]
    type = Transient
    num_steps = 1
    dt = 0.1
[]
  
[Adaptivity]
    max_h_level = 2
    initial_steps = 2
    initial_marker = marker
    [Indicators]
      [indicator]
        type = GradientJumpIndicator
        variable = u
      []
    []
    [Markers]
      [marker]
        type = ErrorFractionMarker
        indicator = indicator
        refine = 0.9
      []
    []
[]
  
[Outputs]
    exodus = true
[]

Step 2: NS Solution Script
mu = 1.1
rho = 1

[Mesh]

    [adapt]
        type = FileMeshGenerator
        file =adapt_mesh_creation_out.e
    []

    [ed0]
        type = BlockDeletionGenerator
        input = adapt
        block = '1'
        new_boundary ='void_surface'
    []



[]

[Modules]
  [NavierStokesFV]
    compressibility = 'incompressible'
    porous_medium_treatment = true

    density = 'rho'
    dynamic_viscosity = 'mu'
    porosity = 'funcporosity'

    initial_velocity = '1e-6 1e-6 0'
    initial_pressure = 0.0

    inlet_boundaries = 'left'
    momentum_inlet_types = 'fixed-pressure'
    momentum_inlet_function = '1'
    outlet_boundaries = 'right'
    momentum_outlet_types = 'fixed-pressure'
    pressure_function = '0'

    wall_boundaries = 'top bottom void_surface '
    momentum_wall_types = 'noslip noslip noslip'
    

    friction_types = 'darcy '
    friction_coeffs = 'Darcy_coefficient'

    mass_advection_interpolation = 'average'
    momentum_advection_interpolation = 'average'
  []
[]

[FunctorMaterials]
  [const]
    type = GenericFunctorMaterial
    prop_names = 'rho mu'
    prop_values = '${rho} ${mu}'
    outputs = exodus
  []
  [friction]
    type = GenericVectorFunctorMaterial
    prop_names = 'Darcy_coefficient '
    prop_values = '0.1 0.1 0.1'
    outputs = exodus
  []

  [jump]
    type = PiecewiseByBlockFunctorMaterial
    prop_name = 'funcporosity'
    subdomain_to_prop_value = '0 0.1
                               1 0.1'
    outputs = exodus
  []

[]



[Executioner]
    type = Transient
    dt = 1.0
    solve_type = 'PJFNK'
    steady_state_detection = true
    steady_state_tolerance = 1E-8
    petsc_options_iname = ' -pc_type -pc_asm_overlap  -sub_pc_type -sub_pc_factor_shift_type -ksp_type  '
    petsc_options_value = 'asm 2 lu NONZERO gmres'
    nl_rel_tol = 1e-11
    nl_abs_tol = 1e-14
  []
  
  
  [Outputs]
    exodus = true
    print_linear_residuals = true 
    print_nonlinear_residuals = true
    #print_perf_log = true 
  
  []

Random_Spheres_25x_01.png:

I then read in the refined mesh
file =adapt_mesh_creation_out.e

we cant read exodus files with adaptivity refinement patterns. You ll have to use the Checkpoint format (for both writing in the first simulation and reading in the second) so that we read it properly
if you used a MeshDiagnosticsGenerator on your final mesh you would see it was read with tons of non-conformalities.

Thanks Guillaume! Is there an example of this beyond what's available here: https://mooseframework.inl.gov/source/outputs/Checkpoint.html
Also is there a way I can do this all in one script that I am just not understanding?

It's just writing then reading. You can look at test/tests/checkpoint, maybe there's an example there?
To restart the variables from a checkpoint, use the parameters in the problem (restart_file_base notably)
But yes you are right. You could do this in one step. Just use a step of 'initial' adaptivity instead of regular adaptivity.
The parameters for initial adaptivity are specified in the same block

node.title: Beam functions for beam or beam elements?
node.bodyText: Are the utility functions for the Timoshenko beam like InertialForceBeam for the entire beam or a beam element? For example, if I use a 1D mesh with nx=10, do I need to provide Iy and Iz for the entire beam or for just 1/10nth of the beam for InertialForceBeam?
@cbolisetti
They're block restricted. So if you enter a function that varies Ix, Iy in space, it will be used for the elements in the whole block. The block can have any number of elements you want.

@cbolisetti Thank you for your answer. To be honest though, I din't quite understand what you mean. Suppose I create a mesh using
[Mesh]
  [mesh]
    type = GeneratedMeshGenerator
    dim = 1
    nx = 10
    xmin = 0.0 # [m]
    xmax = 1.6 # [m]
  []
[]

and I want to model a beam of length 1.6m. Just so that we use the some notation. This beam would have 10 elements, correct? This beam has just one Ix, one Iy and one Iz. Each element (having the same length 0.16m), would have its own set of values Ix,Iy,Iz. What do the values Iy,Iz that I pass to InertialForceBeam refer to?
Somehow I would assume that if I pass just one value (Iy = 7.33653e-8), it applies it to all of them? However, there is no error when I pass two values ('7.33653e-8 6.33653e-8'), which doesn't make any sense. So, I am quite confused how this all adds up.
Your help would be much appreciated.

Looks like I misunderstood your question. If you use one number in this case, it will be applied to all 10 elements. In this case you only have one block, which is the default. I think if you enter multiple values they will be applied to multiple blocks. I am not sure why there's no error thrown in this case..probably an oversight.

@cbolisetti thank you again for your answer. So to conclude this. If I use a single value for Iy, for example. Does that value refer to the Iy for one element out of the ten (in the above example) or for the entire beam?
In your case, that should apply for the entire beam.

node.title: Have MOOSE output files outside of moose project folder
node.bodyText:
I am trying to output outside of my project folder named Tarpon. I am trying to output to a folder I use for some MATLAB post-processing; however, moose will not identify the home path. Instead of going to:
Home/Main/Data
MOOSE creates a new file path inside itself:
Home/projects/tarpon/Home/Main/Data
How can I make moose output outside of itself? There is not much documentation on file_base
[Outputs]
file_base = Home/Main/Data/3d2
[./exodus]
type = Exodus
interval = 1
#sync_times = '1000 1200'
file_base = Home/Main/Data/3d2
[../]
csv = true
checkpoint = true
[]

Hello
You can either use ../../ etc to get out of the folder where the input is run.
Or you can try an absolute path ~/Home/Main/Data
Either should be supported though I have only tested the former
Guillaume

Thank you. Using "../../" worked perfectly.
I tried using the absolute path first, but it kept just making a folder named "~".

node.title: The interface protocol
node.bodyText:
Hello, I would like to package my program into the MOOSE framework. How can I find the interface protocol information of MOOSE and integrate it into MOOSE in a standardized manner? I have not found any relevant instructions on the official website yet.
yours,
lvkas

Hello
The recommended way is to create an ExternalProblem class and set up the execution logic for your external program there.
You can look to cardinal as an example of executing external programs within MOOSE
https://github.com/neams-th-coe/cardinal
Guillaume

node.title: BreakMeshByBlockGenerator interface
node.bodyText: Hello, what exactly differs when using the add_interface_on_two_sides = true, shouldn't it be giving the same results overall?

Hello
The sideset is being added on both sides of the cut
As opposed to being only on one side
It's usually more a matter of needing the two sidesets for some model that relies on both, for example a contact model.
If you only have one side, then you cant use the model
Guillaume

node.title: Multiphase Multicomponent Microstructure Simulation
node.bodyText:
Hello Moose Community,
I hope you all are doing great.  I am here with a request to help me simulate the microstructure of a Multicomponent Multiphase alloy system using Moose at different heat treatment conditions. I am very new to phase field simulation and also to Moose. Request you to kindly help me in this regard.
I have experience in CALPHAD simulation.
Thanks for your time.
@amjokisaari @laagesen

Hello and thanks for your interest in the MOOSE framework! Where are you located? If you are able to attend the upcoming MOOSE training workshop this summer, that would help you get up to speed quickly:
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/training/index.html
